We modeled the transmission process in Republic of Korea and Italy 28 with a stochastic model and estimated the basic reproduction number R 0 as 2.6 (95% 29 CI: 2.3-2.9) or 3.2 (95% CI: 2.9-3.5) in Republic of Korea, under the assumption that 30 the exponential growth starting on 31 January or 5 February 2020, and 2.6 (95% CI: 31 2.3-2.9) or 3.3 (95% CI: 3.0-3.6) in Italy, under the assumption that the exponential 32 growth starting on 5 February or 10 February 2020. An evaluation version of novaPDF was used to create this PDF file. Purchase a license to generate PDF files without this notice.

The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) first emerged in Wuhan, China in the end 42 of 2019 and spread to more than 60 foreign countries as of 1 March 2020 [1] . On 20 43 January 2020, the first imported COVID-19 case was detected in Republic of Korea, 44 and the epidemic curve appeared steadily until 15 February. In the second half of 45
February, the number of reported cases increased rapidly with more than 1200 cases a 46
week. As of 5 March 2020, there were 6088 cases confirmed including 41 deaths [1] . 47

In Italy, the first case was reported on 6 February 2020 and the epidemic curve was The onset date of each secondary case is the summation of the onset date of the 65 primary case (t) plus the serial interval (SI). In this work, the SI was assumed as a 66
Gamma distribution with a 4.5-day mean and a 3.1-day standard deviation (SD) [3] [4] [5] . 67

The transmission process was simulated stochastically. 68 69 An evaluation version of novaPDF was used to create this PDF file. The R 0 was estimated by the maximum likelihood estimates 75 approach that fit the reported cases with Poisson-distributed likelihood framework as 76 follows. 77
Here, the l(•) is the overall log-likelihood and T is the total number of days since the 79 start of exponential growth. The n t represents number of cases reported on t-th day. 80
We calculated 95% confidence intervals (95%CI) by using the profile likelihood 81 estimation approach determined by a Chi-square quantile. 82 83

In Table 1 , we estimated the R 0 in Republic of Korea at 2.6 (95% CI: 2.3−2.9) and 3.2 86 (95% CI: 2.9−3.5) with the transmission starting date on 31 January and 5 February 87 2020, and the R 0 in Italy at 2.6 (95% CI: 2.3-2.9) and 3.3 (95% CI: 3.0-3.6), with the 88 transmission starting date on 5 February and 10 February 2020. FIGREF2.text: 48 steadily by 21 February. Then the number of reported cases soared rapidly, 49 reaching 3142 reported cases and 107 deaths until 5 March 2020 [1]. To date, there 50 are 14768 confirmed cases in the world except China, which means that more than 60 51 per cent of cases outside China are from Republic of Korea and Italy. 52 In this study, we modelled the early outbreak of COVID-19 in Republic of Korea and 53 Italy to estimate the basic reproduction number under different exponential growth 54 collect time series of reported COVID-19 cases in Republic of Korea from 20 59 January to 1 March 2020 and cases in Italy from 5 February to 5 March 2020. 60 Following [2], we assumed that number of secondary cases associated with a primary 61 COVID-19 case follows a negative binomial (NB) distribution, with means R 0 and 62 dispersion parameter k. Here, the R 0 is the basic reproduction number of COVID-19. 63 64

FIGREF3.text: that the fitting results matched the observed number of cases well. Our 91 estimated R 0 in Republic of Korea is relatively higher than that in Shim et al.'s [6], 92 which set the exponential growth starting date on 20 January 2020 and the onset date 93 data were considered. Here we use laboratory confirmation date data which covered 94 both symptomatic and asymptomatic cases. In addition, the R 0 estimates from two 95 countries were largely consistent with those estimates in Wuhan, Hubei, China [7]. If 96 there were evidences suggesting that the exponential growth started earlier, we note 97 that the R 0 estimates would decrease. Public activities in the late date and cold 98 weather in our study period could have speed up the transmission which explains the 99 higher estimates. 100 101 An evaluation version of novaPDF was used to create this PDF file. TABREF0.text: we show the daily reported cases and their instantaneous 111 reproductive number (Re) using the R package EpiEstim [10] with the same 112 aforementioned SI distribution. Their initial instantaneous reproductive number may 113 be regarded as the basic reproductive number. The pink bold curve shows the 114 estimates of Re with a 95% confidence interval. The epidemic will fade out when the 115Re is below 1. In principle, only local cases should be used, which is true for all 116 countries except for China, where the second wave is largely due to imported cases. 117 The summary of the basic reproduction number estimates under different 119 exponential growth starting date. 120
